docs.snippet: Why Thomas Piketty doesn’t want an award — at least not from the French government....
docs.lead_paragraph: Why Thomas Piketty doesn’t want an award — at least not from the French government.
docs.abstract: Vikas Bajaj Editorial Notebook holds that economist Thomas Piketty's rejection of French government's Legion of Honor Award is significant because it comes at time when France is struggling to revive its economy; reflects that it makes sense that Piketty does not want to share in France's economic missteps.

headline.main: The Legion of Honor? Thomas Piketty Refuses
headline.print_headline: You Want to Honor Me? I Refuse!

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Baranczak defied state censors to write about living under Communist oppression and later emigrated to the United States, where he taught at Harvard.
docs.abstract: Stanislaw Baranczak, Polish poet and essayist who defied state censors to write about living under Communist oppression and who later emigrated to United States, where he taught at Harvard, dies at age 68.

headline.main: Stanislaw Baranczak, 68, Polish Underground Poet, Dies
headline.print_headline: Stanislaw Baranczak, 68, a Polish Underground Poet

docs.snippet: WACHTELL--George. George "Peter" Wachtell, was born March 18, 1923, in Bronx, New York. He passed away peacefully on December 31, 2014, at the age of 91. Dr. Wachtell was predeceased by a son, Seth Daniel Wachtell, who died in 1957, at the age of ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
WACHTELL--George.

George "Peter" Wachtell, was born March 18, 1923, in Bronx, New York. He passed away peacefully on December 31, 2014, at the age of 91. Dr. Wachtell was predeceased by a son, Seth Daniel Wachtell, who died in 1957, at the age of 21 months. Dr. Wachtell is survived by two daughters Janet Wachtell Hadler, of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, and Jahan Jacobson, formerly Susan Wachtell, of Marlton, New Jersey; three grandchildren -Jessica Hadler, Michael Hadler, and Marissa Hadler; and his beloved companion of many years, Marion Steininger, of Voorhees Township, New Jersey. Dr. Wachtell received a Bachelor of Science degree in physics from MIT in 1943. His thesis was on Piezo-electric Studies. He was a contributing author to Volume three of the MIT Radiation Laboratory Series on Radar Beacons. This series summarizes some of the great technical advances made in radar by the United States during World War II. He received his Ph.D. in physics from Princeton University in 1951 and began work at the Franklin Institute (later known at the Franklin Research Center) in 1951. He received the Franklin Institute Scientist of the Year award in 1986. He was recognized as an expert in thermodynamics, heat transfer, supersonic flow, shock waves, chemical kinetics, optic, interior ballistics, electronics and combustion phenomena. His 20 scholarly technical papers on these scientific subjects have been published in numerous journals and transactions. During his more than 30 years at the Franklin Research Center, he made numerous significant engineering and scientific contributions. An FRC colleague offered the following comment: "His brilliance was the most obvious but he made no one feel inferior in his presence." He was a well-rounded individual who loved classical music and literature. "Pete" was also well known for his sense of humor and wit, his kind and gentle spirit, and the twinkle in his eyes that accompanied his boyish grin. He will be greatly missed. The funeral will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan, Sunday, January 4, 2015 at 11:15am, followed by interment at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on- Hudson.

docs.snippet: ROSENBERG--Fred L.,died peacefully a month shy of his 96th birthday while independently living in his new home amid new friends at Kendal on Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 23, 2014. Fred passed ten years to the day after the death of his ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ROSENBERG--Fred L.,died peacefully a month shy of his 96th birthday while independently living in his new home amid new friends at Kendal on Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 23, 2014. Fred passed ten years to the day after the death of his beloved wife of 56 years, artist Joan Mattison Rosenberg, who never left his thoughts. Navy Lieutenant on LST 281 in a D-Day Landing, and later captain of LST 357 in the Pacific, Fred went on to success as textile marketing executive for leading knit firms including Fab Industries, creating many iconic fabrics such as "Supersuede." An avid sportsman, he played outfield for Syracuse University in the Class of 1939, semi- pro baseball in Boston, and into his 90s helped coach and took batting practice with The Kettle softball team in a Central Park league. Published playwright, poet, composer, and spirited performer for friends and family, Fred was a favorite piano pupil of Paul Creston, crooned with an orchestra in college, and was a lifelong student of music, literature and art. Warm, loving and spiritual, Fred is survived by his close sister Janet Black of Pocasset, MA, his dear daughter Vicki Rosenberg, his admiring son Eric and daughter-in-law Helen, and his devoted grandchildren Karen Rosenberg, Stuart M. Rosenberg, and Stuart's wife Halsey Varady. Memorial Service Sunday, January 25, 2015 at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Contributions in Fred's memory may be made to The Art Students League of New York, attn: Joan M. Rosenberg Memorial Scholarship Fund, 215 West 57th St., NYC, NY 10019. 1/3

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, FRED L.

docs.abstract: Algerian author Kamel Daoud is fighting back after his debut novel Meursault, Counter-Investigation garnered not only acclaim, but also calls from an Salafist imam for his execution; has filed criminal complaint over death threats.
